text: PUSHPA BASNET: My kids

Every time, people used to
look at them in a negative way.

Oh, you know, they are
running a small orphanage

or shelter that looks
after the kids [inaudible].

But always, I had
that passion or dream

that people looked at our
butterfly home, they would say,
whose house is that?
Is that a resort?

ANDERSON COOPER:
With the prize money

she received as 2012's
CNN Hero of the Year,

Pushpa took the first step in
making her dream come true--
she bought a plot of land.

The property was high above the
congested and poverty-stricken

areas of Kathmandu,
and a short walk
from the children's school.

PUSHPA BASNET: Kids should
be close to the nature,

because, you know,
all this childhood

life they were spending in
the prison, in a big ward.

ANDERSON COOPER:
In 2015, the home

that Pushpa had long imagined
was on its way to completion.

Four new structures were up, and
construction was in full swing,

with all of Pushpa's
earnings and dreams
invested in the project.
And then, the unthinkable.
[rattling]

PUSHPA BASNET: Suddenly, what
I hear was, you know, people
were screaming, "Earthquake!
Earthquake!"
[shouting indistinctly]

ANDERSON COOPER:
On April 25th 2015,

a 7.8 magnitude
earthquake struck Nepal.

PUSHPA BASNET: My van
was moving up and down.

People were coming in
the road, you know.

I just jumped off from the van
and I said, no, I need to go,

I need to go and save
my kids, you know?

ANDERSON COOPER: More than
8,000 people were killed.

Hundreds of thousands
were left homeless.
Entire villages were flattened.

PUSHPA BASNET: I could
not even think anything.
I was like, this is it.

It's the end of our world, and
it's the end of our family.

ANDERSON COOPER: Remarkably,
all 42 of Pushpa's children
survived.

In the days, weeks, and months
following the earthquake,

Pushpa and her kids took
shelter under a tarp.

Pushpa learned that
her new butterfly
dream home was destroyed.

PUSHPA BASNET: 45 seconds,
everything fell down.
Everything.
My dreams were all scattered.
It was gone.
[music playing]

I literally sat down
and cried like anything.
I could see my dream coming up.

Such a beautiful-- it
was taking a shape.

It was a huge impact on
myself, but I could not

show it, because I
don't want it to prove
that I'm a weak person.
- [singing]

ANDERSON COOPER: Pushpa
says she felt hopeless.

She'd faced challenges before,
but this time she didn't
know how she would rebuild.
[indistinct chatter]

Displaced with 42
kids to care for,

Pushpa says it was
ultimately the children
who rekindled her hope.

PUSHPA BASNET: We
stayed in a field
for almost three, four month.

Every day, I used to see
my kids in the field.

You know, they were
playing, singing, dancing.
- [SINGING

PUSHPA BASNET: And
I think I had a hope

that my kids all are safe,
I'm safe, my family are safe.
I'm a strong person, you know.

I have to be strong for
myself and for my 40
kids living with me.
[cheering]
[clapping]

The life is something that
if it's gone, it's gone.

The house is something
we can redo it.

ANDERSON COOPER: Resilience
and determination have
long defined Pushpa's life.

She was a 21-year-old
college student

when she first learned
about the plight of kids
living in Nepal's prisons.

Alarmed by the discovery,
she soon took action.
[indistinct chatter]

Pushpa started a
nonprofit called ECDC,

Early Childhood
Development Center,
to care for the kids of inmates.

She started with just
four children in 2005,

and grew the program to
care for more than 40.

From Kathmandu,
is Pushpa Basnet.
[cheering]

She'd been at it for
more than a decade,

with little support from local
government or the public,
when CNN Heroes honored her.

PUSHPA BASNET: This
is for my children,

and this is for back
to my country, Nepal.

And thank you so much for
everyone who voted for me
and who believed in my dream.
Thank you.

ANDERSON COOPER:
The global attention

she received when
she was announced

as CNN Hero of the Year was
something altogether new.

PUSHPA BASNET: After becoming
the CNN Hero of 2012,

you know, after
coming back to Nepal,
everything changed in my life.

The first thing I encountered
in the airport was my father.

I've never got a
hug from my father.

I think that was the
first time in my life
that my father hugged me.

And maybe he felt that, oh, I'm
proud of you, what you've done.
[non-english speech]

ANDERSON COOPER: Pushpa
says the spotlight
inspired her to work harder.

Since 2012, she's been able to
substantially reduce the number
of kids living inside prisons.
[indistinct chatter]

She also offers scholarships,
and works with the Nepalese

government to improve
conditions for kids living
in prisons with their parents.

PUSHPA BASNET: We've been
working with 27 prison,

but now our government
are more aware of giving

a right for the kids
living inside the prison.

So almost they have to travel
for two days to come here,

you know, by bus or
by walking, you know,
to get a better future.

But we make sure that they are
connected to their parents,

because that's the most
important thing, you know?

ANDERSON COOPER: After
the earthquake destroyed

her new home, Pushpa's
story of hope and loss

reached millions
around the world.

In 2015, a charity
group in Germany

stepped in and gave
Pushpa the money
she needed to rebuild the house.
[kids squealing]

On February 3rd, 2016, Pushpa
and her children moved in.
[kids squealing]

PUSHPA BASNET: This
is my dream world,

and this is my dream
world for my kids.

We have a separate
building for boys,
a separate building for girls.
- [singing]

PUSHPA BASNET: And we
have [inaudible] room,

we have library, computer
room, a study room.

And we have a kitchen
and an open dining hall.
We have a garden.

We have a solar panel,
which runs the butterfly
home with the solar.
And we have a vegetable garden.

Definitely I think the
most important thing,

we have that love within
ourselves, you know?

ANDERSON COOPER: Today,
Pushpa is 33 years old.

She and her kids are
stronger than ever,

and have plans to open
their home to even
more children in the future.
PUSHPA BASNET: Yay!
[non-english speech]

So I think the
stigma has changed.

Now, people say that
look at these kids,

they have such a
fortune life, you know?

They are blessed to
have a good education,

good environment, good family
and everything, you know?

ANDERSON COOPER:
For Pushpa Basnet,

the last 12 years of
hard work has paid off.

Through her various programs,
she has helped educate and care
for more than 150 kids.

She may be a CNN hero,
but to her children,

she's Mamu, a Nepali
word for mother.
And Mamu has no plans to stop.

PUSHPA BASNET:
[non-english speech]
[laughing]

When someone calls me a
CNN Hero of the Year 2012,

are you Pushpa, when they
call me up, I do blush out.
I do really blush out.
My face color changes.
[clapping and singing]

My kids are my hero, because
they are the one who really
inspire me to do this work.
[clapping and singing]

The hope that I have for
kids living in the prison

or living under the poverty
in Nepal, that all [inaudible]

should have a normal
life, a better education,
a better environment for them.

I would expect them
to get a better

education so that tomorrow
they can have a better future.

But the most important thing
is that what we have to create

is a happy, smiley
face on these kids.
- Bye.

PUSHPA BASNET: For them
to see that, if we dream,

if we have that passion, we
can change the world, you know?

So I think the smile and
the hope and the dream

that they have, I
think yes, that really
keeps me inspired to do more.
- We love Mamu.

ANDERSON COOPER: Pushpa
has been a joy to follow.

Her laughter is contagious,
and her work is improving
the lives of so many children.

If you know someone who
should be a CNN hero,

you can nominate them
right now at cnnheroes.com.
